all_paragraphs: In data science and machine learning, mathematical skills are as important as programming skills. There are so many good packages that can be used for building predictive models. Some of the most common packages for descriptive and predictive analytics include
Thanks to the above-mentioned packages, pretty much everyone with some basic understanding of data science can build a machine learning model.
However, it’s important that before using these packages, you master the fundamentals of data science, that way you are not using these packages simply as blackbox tools.

In this article, we illustrate how in-depth knowledge of the back end of a machine learning algorithm is important and crucial for building efficient and reliable models. We shall consider a case study by using the cruise ship dataset cruise_ship_info.csv to build a model for recommending crew size.

In the previous article (Feature Selection and Dimensionality Reduction Using Covariance Matrix Plot), we’ve shown that a covariance matrix plot can be used for feature selection and dimensionality reduction.

Using the cruise ship dataset cruise_ship_info.csv, we found that out of the 6 predictor features [‘age’, ‘tonnage’, ‘passengers’, ‘length’, ‘cabins’, ‘passenger_density’], if we assume important features have a correlation coefficient of 0.6 or greater with the target variable, then the target variable “crew” correlates strongly with 4 predictor variables: “tonnage”, “passengers”, “length, and “cabins”. We, therefore, were able to reduce the dimension of our feature space from 6 to 4.
Suppose now that we want to build a linear regression model for predicting the “crew” variable using the 4 predictor variables: “tonnage”, “passengers”, “length, and “cabins”.
We would like our model to performs 3 important tasks on the input dataset:
(1) Feature scaling using the StandardScaler() transformer;
(2) Feature engineering and dimensionality reduction using the PCA() transformer; and
(3) Model building using the LinearRegression() estimator.

To build a machine learning model, the user will have to interact with the back end of the machine learning model by feeding data into the model. So as a user, you need to import your dataset, prepare the dataset, and then partition it into train and testing sets. .

Now that you’ve understood the details of how the back end of the machine learning model works, and you’ve prepared your dataset, it’s time to feed the data into the machine learning model. We would like to train, test, and evaluate our model using k-fold cross-validation. In k-fold cross-validation, the dataset is randomly partitioned into training and testing sets. The model is trained on the training set and evaluated on the testing set. The process is repeated k-times. The average training and testing scores are then calculated by averaging over the k-folds.

In summary, we’ve discussed the back end of a machine learning algorithm and why it is important that the user understands in all details how the back end works. Thanks to machine learning packages such as sci-kit learn, TensorFlow, PyTouch, Keras, and Caret, everyone with some basic understanding of data science and machine learning can build a predictive model. However, using any machine learning model as a black box without fully understanding the intricacies of the model will lead to a falsified model.
